metadata.case_name: Udoyaram Bhaniram v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appellant was a Hindu undivided family carrying on business as piecegoods merchants in Calcutta.
Assessment relates to income for year 1946-47, previous year being June 12, 1944 to April 24, 1945.
Appellant filed petition under s. 25A of Income-tax Act, 1922 claiming partition on April 24, 1945.
Income-tax Officer enquired on May 27, 1945 into partition and income, pronounced orders on June 30, 1945.
ITO held partition true, family divided into five groups.
Dispute on six sums aggregating Rs. 2,30,346 shown as sale proceeds of ornaments.
Appellant's case: Jewels sold in six lots at partition, price invested in business; credits relate thereto.
ITO rejected: Appellant's books show ornaments sold, Chunilal Damani's accounts show gold purchase; weight per partition agreement Ex. A 3422 tolas vs purchaser's 3133 tolas.

Appellant explained discrepancy as jewels not pure (alloy, brass); ITO rejected as purchaser deducted negligible impurities, sales in round figures (500 tolas thrice), no jewel list or family accounts showing jewels.
ITO held Rs. 2,30,346 as concealed business profits, included in taxable income; imposed Excess Profits Tax.

Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner (AAC): AAC noted changing versions (alloy/brass to pearls/stones removed, pure gold); jewels generational should have more alloy; round figures suspicious; confirmed ITO.
Family agreement Ex. A dated February 20, 1945 to divide into five branches; Sch. B lists jewels total 3422 tolas.
Proceedings book: Minutes Feb 23, 1945 - remove pearls/stones, engage goldsmith Inderban to break jewels.
Proceedings book: Minutes Feb 28, 1945 - 289 tolas pearls/stones/copper removed; 3133 tolas gold to be sold, proceeds to capital accounts.
Proceedings book: Minutes Apr 21, 1945 - 3133 tolas gold sold, price credited.
Appellant applied to Tribunal to admit proceedings book, claiming filed before ITO; argued Apr 21 minutes translated as Ex. B with endorsement 'Original produced'.
Tribunal refused: Book not initialled by ITO; only Apr 21 minutes possibly shown, not prior ones; not proved same book.
Tribunal held Rs. 2,30,346 secret business profits, dismissed appeals.
Appellant contended s.25A order final on jewels possession/division per Ex.A/B.
Tribunal: s.25A only on partition factum/quantum, no bearing on s.23 assessment.
Calcutta High Court per order Dec 7, 1950 under s.66(2) referred two questions; answered Q1 negative, Q2 affirmative on June 19, 1953.
High Court dismissed leave under s.66A(2); Supreme Court granted special leave under Art.136.
ITO order sheet May 27, 1945 (Ex.D): Evidence listed for credits - assessee books, Chunilal Damani sale statements/rokar/statement; no mention of proceedings book for credits.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was bound by the findings of fact of the Income-tax Officer relating to the nature and division of the assets of the joint family in question which he arrived at in his enquiry under Section 25A of the Indian Income-tax Act?
Whether there was any material or evidence upon which the taxing authorities could legally hold that the amount of Rs. 2,30,346 represented undisclosed profits of the accounting year in question?
Whether there is evidence that the amount represents profits of business chargeable under Excess Profits Tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: In view of ITO order under s.25A, Department cannot contend Rs.2,30,346 not value of family jewels.
Finding that amount is concealed profits unsupported by legal evidence, perverse.
No evidence amount is business profits for Excess Profits Tax.
Proceedings book produced before ITO, ignored; supports sale of gold from broken jewels.

respondent_arguments.text: s.25A order only decides partition, no bearing on s.23 income assessment.
Proceedings book not relied before ITO/AAC for credits; only Apr21 minutes possibly shown; changing stories.
Discrepancies, round figures, no jewel list prove concealed profits.

court_reasoning.text: s.25A enquiry limited to partition factum and shares; income quantum under s.23 separate; s.25A introduced 1928 to prevent tax escape on division post-year-end.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.25A order has no effect on s.23 assessment of total income.

court_reasoning.text: Whether Rs.2,30,346 sale proceeds or concealed profits is pure fact question; attackable only if no evidence or perverse.
Proceedings book not relied before ITO for credits (Ex.D lists other evidence); only Apr21 for partition; not produced to AAC; Tribunal not perverse in refusing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Minutes prior to Apr21 not shown to ITO.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation rejected by all authorities untenable; credits treated as business receipts where source unproved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites V. Govindarajulu Mudaliar: ITO entitled to infer assessable nature if source unproved.

court_reasoning.text: No separate finding needed for EPT if business profits inferred.

holdings.text: Tribunal not bound by s.25A findings on assets for s.23 assessment.
Material/evidence exists to hold Rs.2,30,346 undisclosed business profits.
Where source unproved, infer assessable business profits taxable including under Excess Profits Tax.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. Govindarajulu Mudaliar v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Where assessee fails to prove source of cash receipts, ITO entitled to infer assessable nature.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: s.25A for partition order deeming family undivided for tax apportionment; separate from s.23 income assessment; references under s.66.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1928
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced s.25A to prevent tax escape on post-year division.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Tax imposed on concealed business profits.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding Tribunal and High Court that Rs. 2,30,346 represented concealed business profits taxable under Income-tax Act and Excess Profits Tax Act; s.25A order not binding on s.23 assessment; proceedings book rightly excluded.

key_quotes.text: "There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amounts of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding justifying treatment of unproved credits as taxable profits.

key_quotes.text: The question as to what the income of the family assessable to tax under s. 23 was, would be foreign to the scope of an enquiry under s. 25A.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies separation of s.25A partition enquiry from s.23 income determination.
